title: England star Ross Barkley has perfect response to Roy Keane's brutal comment
text:
England midfielder Ross Barkley had a dream first half against Bulgaria (Picture: Getty)

Manchester United legend Roy Keane took aim at Ross Barkley ahead of England’s Euro 2020 qualifying match with Bulgaria – but the midfielder hit back with two goals and an assist in Sofia.

Racist abuse from home fans at the Vasil Levski National Stadium marred Monday night’s clash as England tightened their grip on top spot in Group A with a comprehensive 6-0 win.

England manager Gareth Southgate was involved in lengthy discussions on the touchline as referee Ivan Bebek twice halted play in the opening 45 minutes.

The PA announcer warned Bulgaria supporters over the chanting, with the match in danger of being abandoned before play was allowed to continue on a shameful night for football.

Racist chanting overshadowed England’s victory in Bulgaria (Picture: Getty)

An FA statement on the racist chanting in Sofia said: ‘The FA can confirm that England players were subjected to abhorrent racist chanting while playing in the EURO 2020 qualifier against Bulgaria.

‘This is unacceptable at any level of the game and our immediate focus is supporting the players and staff involved.

‘As we are sadly aware, this is not the first time our players have been subjected to this level of abuse and there is no place for this kind of behaviour in society, let alone in football.

‘We will be asking UEFA to investigate as a matter of urgency.’

Barkley, who has been a regular in Southgate’s recent squads, made a substitute appearance as England lost their first qualifier in 10 years to Czech Republic on Friday.

On Monday night, Mason Mount dropped out for Chelsea team-mate Barkley in England’s midfield as Southgate made five changes to the side that was defeated in Prague.

Tyrone Mings was handed his debut, while Ben Chilwell, Harry Winks and Marcus Rashford also came into the side.

Barkley completed a first-half brace in Sofia (Picture: Getty)

Barkley’s selection was the topic of heated debate in the ITV studio leading up to kick-off and it’s safe to say Keane isn’t his biggest fan.

Asked about Southgate picking Barkley, Lee Dixon said: ‘He’s had a decent start for Chelsea and then just gone off the boil a bit but, again, where is his best position? Roy, where would you play him?

Advertisement

Advertisement

Keane bluntly replied: ‘Probably on the bench. Particularly in international football.’

It was almost as if Barkley had caught wind of Keane’s comments as he went on to assist Rashford’s sensational opening strike in the 7th minute before finding the net twice himself in an impressing showing.

Barkley’s first goal came in the 20th minute as he poked home Raheem Sterling’s cross from close-range.

England captain Harry Kane then assisted Barkley for England’s third in the 32nd minute before Sterling gave the visitors a four-goal advantage leading into the break.

Southgate made a complaint about the racist chanting in the first half (Picture: Getty)

Speaking after the final whistle, Southgate hit out at the ‘unacceptable’ racist chanting aimed at his England players over the course of the game.

‘I have to say that the officials were onto everything very quickly,’ the England manager told ITV Sport.

‘We reported everything immediately when we heard things. We had constant communication with the officials and referee and I was in contact with the players during the first half in particular and then again at half-time.

‘It’s an unacceptable situation. I think we’ve made two statements really by winning the game but also we have raised the awareness of everybody to the situation.

‘The game was stopped twice and I know for some people that won’t be enough.

‘But I think we as a group were on board with that process.’
